results.title: Stencilling
results.creator_credit: John Dobis, Sheridan Stumm and Discovery Video
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tonia Todman’s craft room”.
Stencilling, a craft that started thousands of years ago with primitive cave painting has become increasingly popular in recent years. It is a very adaptable and creative way for the home decorator to personalise his or her home in a way that is appealing and inexpensive. Tonia Todman tells you all you need to know to be able to enhance your home with charming stencilled designs. Stencils can be applied to your walls, floors, tables, cupboards, beds, boxes, trays, fabrics, the list goes on. Their application can stretch as far as your imagination takes you, to give your home and homeware a unique, picturesque and individual touch. Tonia tells you how to plan and design a stencil, how to transfer designs, how to position and space your stencils for the most effective results, and describes painting techniques and the choice of colour schemes.

results.title: Thee Films: 1950's - 1960's
results.creator_credit: Antony Balch, William S. Burroughs and Psychic Television
results.brief_description: Five short films featuring the poetry and prose of the Beat writers; William Burroughs, Brion Gyson and Ian Somerville. Filmed in New York City, Paris and Tangiers, the films do not use narrative but rather incorporate avant-garde and experimental film techniques. Burroughs’ poetry, and his commitment to homo-eroticism and heroin use, feature prominently in the films. “William buys a parrot”, “The cut-ups” and “Bill and Tony” last a few minutes whilst “Towers open fire” and “Ghosts at no. 9 (Paris)” are longer films. The last film is an hour excerpt of a longer five hour epic.

results.title: Children's circle
results.brief_description: A quality series that brings outstanding children’s books to the screen. The stories bring alive the actual illustrations from the book, through animation and iconographic techniques. Honoured by awards at Film Festivals worldwide, these programs are the perfect bridge between video and reading.

results.title: Rosies walk and 4 other stories
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Freitag, Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s circle”.
A compilation of 5 delightful and timeless children’s stories from around the world. Watch how Rosie the hen on her daily walk, outfoxes the wily fox in “Rosie’s walk” by Pat Hutchins. “The story of Ping” by Marjorie Flack, takes us to China on an adventure with Ping, the duck. Tomie de Paola’s “Charlie needs a cloak” shows how Charlie the shepherd makes his new winter cloak. H.A. Ray’s classic “Curious George rides a bicycle” has delighted readers of all ages while in “Norman the doorman” by Don Freeman, Norman the mouse harbours a secret ambition to be a great artist, while he stands on guard outside the mouse entrance of the Museum of Art.

results.title: From Russia with love
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
This second instalment in the Bond genre is considered by many Bond aficionados as possibly the best blend of adventure, action, gadgetry, tongue in cheek nonsense, romance, and the obligatory high tech gadgetry. This time round the evil SPECTRE organisation has hatched a plan to steal a decoder that will access Russian state secrets and irrevocably unbalance the world order. Secret agent 007 is the only man to stand in their way and it’s up to James Bond (Sean Connery) to seize the device first. It won’t be an east task as he must confront enemies that include Red Grant (Robert Shaw) and the ruthless Rosa Klebb (Lotte Lenya), a former KGB agent with poison tipped shoes. Bond is able to access inside information when he begins romancing a stunning Soviet defector (Daniela Bianchi), but he quickly realises that he is being lured into a trap that will require all his wit, charm, ability, and gadgetry to save the day. With the stunning backdrop of Istanbul and Venice, ‘From Russia with love’ features an explosive helicopter attack, a gypsy camp gun battle and a brawl aboard the Orient Express. Cast also includes Pedro Armendariz and Bernard Lee.

results.title: Tomorrow never dies [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roger Spottiswoode, Barbara Broccoli, Michael Wilson and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
The 18th in the Bond series finds Bond (Pierce Brosnan) battling crazed media mogul Elliot Carver (Jonathan Pryce) who is intent on starting a war between England and China. His motivation - covering the event on his global satellite network and gaining kudos as the most powerful in current affairs and global business growth. Michelle Yeoh is the beautiful Wai Lin, a Chinese agent who teams up with Bond after crossing paths with him in her pursuit to find out what Carver really is up to. “Tomorrow never dies” is a fast paced action film full of over the top stunts and the usual comedy and sexual innuendo which will delight fans of 007. Cast also includes Dame Judi Dench, Teri Hatcher and Geoffrey Palmer.

results.title: Dr. No
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman, United Artists Corporation and Ken Adam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr. No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist, is a member of the terrorist organisation SPECTRE, which plans to conquer the world. However, thanks to the daring of James Bond, Dr. No is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her screen debut in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme, elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder and the magnificent locations were present from this first film and have now become part of the James Bond legend.

results.title: The World is not enough (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, Danjaq and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Featuring the longest pre credit sequence in the Bond franchise, “The World is not enough” has more than one fiendish villain and a start including a knife throwing sniper, a brief interlude, then an extended powerboat chase on the Thames followed by a hot air balloon. British oil tycoon Sir Robert King is killed via a booby trap at MI6 by a terrorist, thought to be Renard the Anarchist (Robert Carlyle) - an ex KGB agent whose only goal is to create chaos. His claim to fame is a bullet permanently lodged in his head, killing off his senses as well as any feeling of pain, effectively making him super-human. Renard was also responsible for the kidnapping of King’s daughter Elektra (Sophie Marceau) and Bond is sent to protect her and to find the traitor on staff. A ploy is uncovered to steal an atomic missile and use it for sabotage. Nuclear scientist Dr Christmas Jones (Denise Richards) assists Bond is the retrieval process, as well as providing Bond with another potential conquest. Notorious for being the last film in which Q (Desmond Llewelyn) appears, we also see a more humanised M (Judi Dench) and a dazzling array of inventive chase sequences.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Apted, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, Danjaq and United Artists Corporation

A ploy is uncovered to steal an atomic missile and use it for sabotage. Nuclear scientist Dr Christmas Jones (Denise Richards) assists Bond is the retrieval process, as well as providing Bond with another potential conquest. Notorious for being the last film in which Q (Desmond Llewelyn) appears, we also see a more humanised M (Judi Dench) and a dazzling array of inventive chase sequences.
description_for_label:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Featuring the longest pre credit sequence in the Bond franchise, “The World is not enough” has more than one fiendish villain and a start including a knife throwing sniper, a brief interlude, then an extended powerboat chase on the Thames followed by a hot air balloon. British oil tycoon Sir Robert King is killed via a booby trap at MI6 by a terrorist, thought to be Renard the Anarchist (Robert Carlyle) - an ex KGB agent whose only goal is to create chaos. His claim to fame is a bullet permanently lodged in his head, killing off his senses as well as any feeling of pain, effectively making him super-human. Renard was also responsible for the kidnapping of King’s daughter Elektra (Sophie Marceau) and Bond is sent to protect her and to find the traitor on staff. A ploy is uncovered to steal an atomic missile and use it for sabotage. Nuclear scientist Dr Christmas Jones (Denise Richards) assists Bond is the retrieval process, as well as providing Bond with another potential conquest. Notorious for being the last film in which Q (Desmond Llewelyn) appears, we also see a more humanised M (Judi Dench) and a dazzling array of inventive chase sequences.

results.title: Octopussy (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Albert R. Broccoli and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Starting with an impressive sequence involving a small plane and a closing hangar, “Octopussy” also crosses the countries of East Berlin and Delhi and culminates in a train sequence then a big top. When an agent is found dead in East Berlin clutching a Faberge egg, British intelligence is alerted to the flurry of fake Faberges on the market from an unknown source - possibly Russian (alarm bells ring). The mission is code-named Operation Treasure Trove; Secret agent 007 (Roger Moore) placed in charge of proceedings. His mission takes him to Delhi in pursuit of exiled Indian Prince Kamal Khan (Louis Jordan), suspected owner of the Faberge eggs. He is not the top of the chain however, that honour lies with the mysterious Octopussy (Maud Adams), head of a floating harem of acrobatic women who have joined her sisterhood as a way of life, and agreed to taking part in smuggling jewellery and the circus Octopussy is running. Highlights include a snake charming agent, a hair raising tuk tuk ride, a jungle chase complete with elephants, tigers, snakes and a leech, death by circular saw, and the sight of Roger Moore in a clown suit.

results.title: Dr. No (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Terence Young, Albert R. Broccoli, Harry Saltzman, United Artists Corporation and Ken Adam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Dr.No was the first extraordinary adventure of the world’s most famous spy: James Bond. Sean Connery is 007: suave, charming and fearless; an expert on weapons, women, martinis and just about everything. Dr. No, a fanatical scientist plots to overtake the world but is ultimately defeated. Ursula Andress made her first screen appearance in the film. While there is no famous title song, the well-known James Bond theme and elaborate opening title sequences by Maurice Binder have become part of the James Bond legend.
